answer_html: So, by the Squeeze Theorem, \(\left\{ \frac{\sin(n)}{\ln(n)} \right\}_{n=2}^{\infty}=\left\{ \frac{\sin(n)}{\ln(n)} \right\}_{n=2}^{\infty}\) converges to \(\displaystyle {0}.\)
answer_latex:
So, by the Squeeze Theorem,
$\left\{ \frac{\sin(n)}{\ln(n)} \right\}_{n=2}^{\infty}=\left\{ \frac{\sin(n)}{\ln(n)} \right\}_{n=2}^{\infty}$ converges to
$\displaystyle {0}.$
hints_html:
\(|\sin n| \leq 1.\)

What do you know about products where one term is bounded and the other converges to zero?

converges to zero?
hints_raw:
<math> |\sin n| \leq 1. </math>
What do you know about products where one term is bounded and the other converges to zero?
question: 1 (e)
sols_html:
For \(n \geq 2\), we have

\(\left| \frac{\sin(n)}{\ln(n)}\right| \leq \frac{1}{\ln(n)} \quad \textstyle{ \text{ and } } \quad \displaystyle{ \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{\ln(n)} = 0 }.\).

So, by the Squeeze Theorem, \(\left\{ \frac{\sin(n)}{\ln(n)} \right\}_{n=2}^{\infty}\) converges to \(\displaystyle {0}.\)
sols_latex:
For $n \geq 2$, we have

$\left|  \frac{\sin(n)}{\ln(n)}\right| \leq \frac{1}{\ln(n)}  \quad \textstyle{ \text{ and } } \quad
\displaystyle{ \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{\ln(n)} = 0 }.$.

So, by the Squeeze Theorem,
$\left\{ \frac{\sin(n)}{\ln(n)} \right\}_{n=2}^{\infty}$ converges to
$\displaystyle {0}.$
sols_raw:
For <math> n \geq 2 </math>, we have 

<math>  
\left|  \frac{\sin(n)}{\ln(n)}\right| \leq \frac{1}{\ln(n)}  \quad \textstyle{ \text{ and } } \quad
\displaystyle{ \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{\ln(n)} = 0 }.  
</math>. 

So, by the Squeeze Theorem, <math> \left\{ \frac{\sin(n)}{\ln(n)} \right\}_{n=2}^{\infty} </math> converges to <math> \displaystyle{0}. </math>
statement_html:
For this question, the exam asks to put your answer in the box provided but also to show your work. This question is worth 3 marks. Full marks is given for correct answers placed in the box and at most 1 mark is given for an incorrect answer. You are required to simplify your answers as much as possible.

Determine whether the sequence is convergent or divergent. In case it is convergent, compute its limit:

\[\begin{aligned} \left\{ \frac{\sin(n)}{\ln(n)} \right\}_{n=2}^{\infty}\end{aligned}\]
